isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - DRIVETRAIN FAILURE ANALYSIS - AXLE COMPONENTS - PLANETARY UNIT

step1.para: Gear and pinion teeth pitted and spalled. This is generally caused by continuous overloading which breaks down the lubrication film and pitting occurs or contaminated lube. The pitting starts below the tooth centerline then works its way above the centerline. Continued operation causes flakes of metal to break off until spalling occurs ( Figure 65and Figure 66).

Broken teeth on sliding clutch gear ( Figure 67). A severe shock load caused four teeth to fracture that were in mesh with the idler pinions. This occurred when the vehicle was started in high range under heavy load.

figure.caption: Figure 67. Broken Teeth on Sliding Clutch Gear

step1.para: Excessively worn clutch plates and gear. Incorrect shifting caused excessive wear to the sliding clutch gear ( Figure 68) and the sliding shifting plates ( Figure 69).

figure.caption: Figure 68. Excessive Wear to Sliding Clutch Gear
Figure 69. Excessive Wear to Sliding Shifting Plates

step1.para: Normal and excessive wear on the idler pin ( Figure 70). The area labeled normal wear is acceptable for reuse. A idler pin appearing as that labeled excessive wear must be replaced.

figure.caption: Figure 70. Normal and Excessive Wear on Idler Pin

step1.para: Scored and worn idler pin ( Figure 71). This condition could be from normal wear or contaminated lubricant. The discoloration could also indicate overheating or a low lubricant level.

figure.caption: Figure 71. Scored and Worn Idler Pin
